abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Second State Pension
            Reform Technical Assistance Project (PARSEP II) for Brazil
            were as follows: outcomes were moderately unsatisfactory,
            the risk to development outcome was substantial, the Bank
            performance was moderately unsatisfactory, and the Borrower
            performance was also moderately unsatisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: a lesson is that small operations can have
            a big impact. Despite the relative small size of this
            operation (US$ 5 million), its implementation strengthened
            institutional capacity in 15 states and 43 government
            institutions, with annual potential savings accounting for
            over US$26.2 million and an internal rate of return of 195
            percent. The strong commitment of the current federal
            administration in reforming pension management and
            implementing a strong anticorruption agenda shows the ex
            post relevance of these operations. In the particular case
            of PARSEP II, the project's activities conveyed a clear
            anti-corruption message in the participating states, in
            particular in Federal District of Brasilia. Projects that
            involve relatively large and complex procurement processes
            should consider additional and enhanced support from at
            least part-time consultants with solid experience in Bank
            procurement processes and rules, in particular at the
            beginning. For this project, while the change in the
            strategy for procurement management, from hiring United
            Nations Development Program (UNDP) as an intermediate agency
            to managing procurement in-house, is commendable, additional
            procurement support should have been considered at the
            beginning of project implementation until capacities at the
            Project Coordinating Unit (PCU) have been adequately strengthened.
